content.value: Linux is a free and open-source operating system that manages computer hardware and software resources and allows users to interact with the system using graphical interfaces or command-line tools.
content.example: Example: Ubuntu, Fedora, and CentOS are popular Linux operating systems.

content.value: An operating system (OS) is the main software that controls a computer. It acts as a bridge between the user and the hardware. Without an operating system, a computer cannot perform tasks like running applications, managing files, or connecting to the internet.

Linux was created in 1991 by a student named Linus Torvalds. He wanted to build a free operating system kernel that anyone could use, modify, and share. Over time, developers from around the world contributed to Linux, making it powerful, stable, and secure.

items: To create a free alternative to expensive operating systems
To allow users to modify and customize the system
To build a stable and secure operating system

content.value: Open source means that the source code of software is publicly available and anyone can view, modify, and distribute it legally.
content.example: Example: Linux source code can be downloaded and customized by anyone.

items: Highly secure due to community review

content.value: Linux is known for its performance, security, and flexibility. Unlike many commercial operating systems, Linux does not require expensive licenses and works efficiently even on older hardware.
